WRITING.TITLE: What's the weirdest commercial you've ever seen?
Have you ever been creeped out watching a movie alone in a theater?
WRITING.TEXT: Has there ever been a time where you were the only one in a theater, and it made the movie creepier to watch? Like if it was a horror movie, or something like that. When I went to see Coraline on a weekday evening after school, the only people in the theater were a mom and her daughter sitting near the front. It really creeped me out.

WRITING.TITLE: Has season 5 finished production?
WRITING.TEXT: Considering how all of season 3 aired last in year in a giant steven bomb, do you think we'll get another Summer of Steven this year? I wonder how much of season 5 will air this summer. I imagine they have quite a few episodes already completed.
Glass, the sequel to Split that's slated for release in January 2019. It's time for the next movie in the Shyamalanadingdong trilogy.
Hooked on a Feeling.

WRITING.TITLE: In Unbreakable, what if the son had shot Bruce Willis?
WRITING.TEXT: I watched Unbreakable for the first time a few nights ago. During that intense scene where the son (Joseph) finds the gun and almost shoots his father in order to prove he's unbreakable, what if the kid had actually pulled the trigger? Do you think Bruce Willis/David Dunn would have been killed or at least severely hurt?

WRITING.TITLE: Most effective jump scares in non-horror films?
WRITING.TEXT: Jump scares in horror movies are very common, and it's something we've all come to expect. However, what do you think are some effective jump scares in non-horror movies? The Lord of the Rings scene with Bilbo (you know the one) is usually the first one that comes to mind for me, but I recently watched Unbreakable for the first time and it had some effective jump scares towards the end. That scene where Bruce Willis opens the door and sees the homeowner dead and bloody on the floor was pretty disturbing.

WRITING.TITLE: What's the weirdest music video you've ever seen?

WRITING.TEXT: Even for a grown man, Dennis seemed almost freakishly strong. The movie implied he would have tossed the girls around like fluffy pillows if they ganged up on him.
Anyone?

I went to Papa Bear Restaurant, and because the waitress' shift was ending in 20-30 minutes, she was trying to rush my friend and I out the door and get us to leave quickly. For example, asking us if we were ready to order literally 15 seconds after we sat down, giving us the bill *while we were trying to enjoy our fucking meal*, etc...
In Split, when the Beast kills the old lady by giving her a violent bear hug that snaps her spine.
Leeeeearning!
Cheesecake Factory. Yes, I went there. Great cheesecake aside (albeit pretty overpriced), I can't even remember what I freakin ordered for my main entree last time I was there.
The scene in Wreck-It Ralph where Ralph destroys the kart in front of Vanellope. One of the saddest things I've ever seen in a movie. I know Disney loves to pull your heartstrings...but, holy shit!

Considering the movie has been delayed multiple times (it was supposed to get a theatrical release in March), and is now going direct to video in July, it doesn't surprise me this movie is trash. Is there a twist, by the way?

WRITING.TITLE: Has anyone seen the bullying movie Sticks and Stones?
WRITING.TEXT: It's one of those movies that's faded into complete obscurity, and you never hear a word about it. But anyway, has anyone here seen it? You can find it on YouTube, and it's a 90's movie about bullying. Despite it's cheesiness (and trust me, this movie is the very definition of cliche and cheesy), it's definitely one of the most intense movies about bullying I've seen. I was surprised at how crude and violent the movie got at times with the bullying. The whole situation with the bully felt a bit unrealistic, though. It seems like all 3 of the kids could have collectively brushed him off. They made it seem like the bully was some super powerful force of nature.

Shyamalan is known for his twists, but you're really overthinking it. There's no way he would go as far to have us think the flashbacks belong to Casey if they were really Kevin's all along. Besides, in an interview for the movie, M Night was talking about Casey in the flashbacks and said something to the effect of - "She had this traumatic experience with her uncle". Shyamalan referring to the kid in those flashbacks as a "she" clearly means those flashbacks are of Casey when she was little girl.
As for how the Beast formed, remember Kevin works at a zoo as a janitor. The Beast originated from the animals he saw on a daily basis, hence the Beast having tough skin like a rhino and being able to run fast, climb walls, and even bend steel bars. Not to mention the way he devoured those two girls is the same way a hungry lion or tiger devours its helpless prey. The Beast has traits of several zoo animals, and Patricia also mentions this. Also, I think Dennis was the personality that formed from Kevin's abuse by his mom. Kevin's mom was a neat freak who would abuse him if things weren't clean, and that's how Dennis formed. Hence why he has OCD and wants everything super clean.
The Lone Ranger. That movie was hot garbage. Nuff said.
Jungle Book 2 and Peter Pan 2 are Disney sequels that were released to theaters, however.
Extremely Goofy Movie was direct to video.
Are people forgetting that The Jungle Book 2 and Peter Pan 2 are both Disney sequels that were theatrically released?

The Wild (2006) is one of those Disney films you NEVER hear people talk about nowadays. It's a movie that's pretty much faded into complete obscurity, and for good reason. It's just a boring, charmless, ugly rip-off of Madagascar and the Lion King. That sub-plot about the wildebeest wanting to eat lions was ridiculous too.

Say my name.
SAY IT!!!!
Cars 3 is going to destroy The Book of Henry (both movies are being released on June 16th). Sorry, Colin Trevorrow.

I'm glad to hear Anya Taylor-Joy will be returning as Casey. Also, I hope we find out what happened to Casey's uncle. I know the look she gave the police officer hinted she would turn him in, but I want to see him pay.
The treasure hunt in Zelda the Wind Waker. Fuck that!

For me at least, The Book of Henry will either make or break Colin Trevorrow as a director. The fact that the movie has gotten so little advertising or recognition, and is being released the same day as Cars 3, has me worried.
I enjoyed it, especially from a visual perspective, but the story needed some work.
Wreck it Ralph

It's kinda disappointing PSH didn't get more screen-time in MI3, at least in my opinion. Not to mention that one of his scenes (near the end) is just a replay of the intense opening scene. He didn't have to be in every scene, but one more scene where we see just how menacing he is would have been nice. Like if we saw him talking to Ethan's wife shortly after she was captured.
Owen Davian's speech in Mission Impossible 3 about how he's gonna hunt down Ethan's wife and make her bleed and cry.

One of the girls suggested all 3 of them attack Dennis at once, but Casey knew it wouldn't work. Even Patricia (the female personality) recovered really fast from being hit in the back with a chair. I think the only one they could have really overpowered was Hedwig.
I can't wait to see Chris Suckmann review this movie.

WRITING.TITLE: Do you think Fire in the Sky should have gotten an R-rating?
WRITING.TEXT: This is inspired by a recent discussion from when someone posted that abduction clip from Fire in the Sky. Looking back, how did the movie only manage to get a PG-13 rating? I mean, sure almost nothing happens for a large amount of the movie, but the abduction scene on the table is basically torture porn. The movie doesn't really have any blood or gore, but those torture scenes are absolutely horrifying to watch. Heck, I've even seen plenty of R-rated movies which don't even come close to being that graphic. The movie should have gotten an R-rating. Anyone else agree?
Shrek The Third is the most godawful piece of garbage I've ever seen...and I'll just leave it at that. Seriously, my hatred for that movie is almost irrational.

The dream sequence after the little girl falls and hits her head is the most bizarre and surreal piece I've ever seen in a movie. It really freaked me out when I first saw it, especially when she's a doll and they're opening her cracked head.

Was the food on Pale Man's table supposed to be enchanted? No one would be that foolish to eat a grape on the table after seeing a pile of children's shoes in the corner, and pictures of that hideous frail thing eating children. Ofelia was really asking for it.
Ha ha, and not a single response. I think I've proved my point.

WRITING.TITLE: The Book of Henry is really flying under the radar
WRITING.TEXT:
Anyone else agree? There doesn't really seem to be much advertising or recognition for this movie...like at all. Also, the trailer was just released at the end of March, which is basically 2 and 1/2 months before its release (June 16th). I hope it doesn't bomb, since it's debuting the same day as Cars 3, and it also has to go against Captain Underpants and Transformers.
Now as for the trailer itself, it looks interesting, but I don't know what to think of it.

Go to your *ROOOOOOOM!*
I'm already in my room!

WRITING.TITLE: Free $20.00 Uber Ride: AARONS22984UE
WRITING.TEXT: With this promo code, get up to $20 off your first ride with Uber.
Yep, I'm referring to the animated movie. Hard to believe it's the same studio that's now making movies like The Boss Baby and Trolls.

WRITING.TITLE: All Dogs Go To Heaven - Hell Nightmare (Uncut)

WRITING.TEXT: The Prince of Egypt is a fantastic piece of work. The visuals are breathtaking, and the movie has some amazing sequences such as Moses' nightmare about hieroglyphics.
Inconceivable!
This scene is nothing short of torture porn. Seriously, how is this movie only rated PG-13? I've seen R-rated films which don't even come close to being this violent and horrifying.
Kevin James. Whether it's "Hitch" or "Mall Cop", he's always playing the hopeless loser.
Jaden Smith was surprisingly good in the movie. Not sure what the hell happened in After Earth...he was awful.
Nedry's death in the book is even more gruesome.

WRITING.TITLE: Happy Feet is a great movie to watch when you're stoned.
WRITING.TEXT:
Happy Feet is without a doubt, one of the weirdest movies I've ever seen. I mean, it's just so bizarre. It's like a mishmash of High School Musical, March of the Penguins, and an episode of the Twilight Zone. It has no idea what it wants to be half of the time, and by the time Mumble goes insane in the mental hospital zoo, it's like something out of a Stephen King narration. The propaganda stuff didn't even bother me that much...at least not in comparison to how weird the movie is.
It's a great movie to watch when you're stoned. Anyone agree?
Agreed. Also, I have a theory that the uncle is responsible for Casey's father's death, and that he (the uncle) killed the father knowing that he would have full custody of Casey.
In Scooby Doo Mystery Incorporated, he was Sheriff Kronk.

People were probably upset about the scene because she's a woman. I mean, if that had been a male character who died that horrific death, no one would have batted an eye. But because she's female...STOP THE PRESSES EVERYONE!

I think people made too big of a fuss about Peter accidentally hitting Mary Jane in Spider-Man 3. He thought Mary Jane was one of the club bouncers. Seriously, some people acted like Peter was an abusive wife beater. It's another example of how women are allowed to hit or strike a man, but the second a man does the same thing, even if it's on accident...STOP THE PRESSES!

The Bilbo Baggins scene in LOTR.
You know the one.

Any gay panic caused by scenes from movies that aren't even out. See ParaNorman, Finding Dory, and Beauty and the Beast. I never saw ParaNorman...
Here's the gay scene from ParaNorman, in case you're curious.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nel883o_6SA
All work and no play makes Joker a dull boy.
Has the show been renewed for a season 6?
After Earth
Omelette Du Fromage

WRITING.TITLE: Movies where you can't see the past the actor or voice actor?
WRITING.TEXT: Whether it's an animated movie or live action film, what are some movies where you just can't see past the actor or voice actor? In other words, the person's voice is so distinct or maybe you're so familiar with the actor, you don't see them as the character they're playing? For example, in the most recent Jungle Book movie, everytime Kaa opened its mouth, all I heard was Scarlett Johansson trying to voice a snake. Her voice was just too distinct.
Happy Feet is a great movie to watch when you're stoned.
Rush Hour is pretty fucking bad.
I don't like Star Wars fans. They're coarse, rough, irritating, and they get everywhere.

I'll probably get downvoted into oblivion, but did anyone else think Shyamalan could have handled the childhood flashbacks scenes better? I understand Casey being molested is a part of her character and it's what saved her from the Beast, but that one flashback in particular was just too much for me. I didn't need to see a grown man strip naked in the woods and get on all fours like some greasy pedobear. That was just fucked up.

He has no reason to leave. When I drop passengers off anywhere commercial I tend to stay.
It wasn't that the driver didn't leave, as much as it my suspicions that he was waiting outside because he was getting ready to call the police. I definitely think he would've had I stayed at the store any longer. He wasn't playing around, and was also on the phone with someone when my new driver came to pick me up.
Now approaching the other driver too is legitimate if a driver had concerns over a scam.
Of course it's legitimate, but outright telling the other driver that I plan to cancel and scam them, on the other hand, is not.

WRITING.TITLE: As a passenger, have you ever accidentally cancelled a ride during your trip?
WRITING.TEXT:
It happened to me the other night. When I was on the way home after seeing the new Power Rangers, I was messing with the Lyft app and I accidentally cancelled. The driver thought I was trying to scam him. I tried explaining to him, but he didnt believe me at all. He dropped me off at a nearby store, and told me to get out. I thought he would leave afterwards, but he didnt. Now, this is when things started to get intense.
I requested another ride, and when a new driver showed up at the store, I noticed the other driver was still waiting outside. He ran up to the car window, and started trying to convince the new driver that I was scamming and planning to cancel. Ok, I don't mind the driver getting mad and dropping me off after I cancelled (even if I cancelled by accident), but he really should have left after dropping me off. At the very least, don't try convincing other drivers that I'm planning to scam. It seemed like he was one step away from calling the police. Oh well, at least I contacted Lyft and they said they'd pay the driver back.
